revision.text:
{{Infobox wildfire | title = Cold Fire (2016) | caption = Smoke from the Cold Fire blankets the hills off highway 128 in Winters, with flames becoming visible on a hilltop as the fire grows by the end of its first night to 1,700 acres. August 2nd, 2016. | image = | location = [[Vaca Mountains]],
[[Yolo County, California|Yolo County]],
[[California]] | coordinates = {{coord|38.52513|-122.06788|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = California | pushpin_map_caption = Location in California | cost = $100,000 | date = {{Start date|2016|8|2}} - {{End date|2016|8|11}} | area = {{convert|5,371|acre|ha|0|abbr=on}} | cause = Under investigation | buildings = 2 | injuries = | perps = | motive = | reference ={{cite web|title=Cold Fire|url=http://cdfdata.fire.ca.gov/incidents/incidents_details_info?incident_id=1366|website=Incident Information|publisher=Cal Fire|accessdate=3 August 2016}}{{cite web|title='Cold Fire' contained after burning 5,731 acres|url=http://napavalleyregister.com/news/local/cold-fire-contained-after-burning-acres/article_f77b8dee-cac1-59c1-a046-4c5c56f151e9.html|website=Napa Valley Register|accessdate=15 August 2016}} }} The '''Cold Fire''' was a [[wildfire]] that started on August 2, 2016 in the [[Vaca Mountains]], near [[Lake Berryessa]] and just west of the city of [[Winters, California|Winters]], in [[Yolo County, California|Yolo County]], northern California. The fire was contained by 6 PM on August 11 after burning a total of {{convert|5,371|acres|km2}}, including two buildings, causing an estimated $100,000 in damage. ==Events== The fire was first reported at 4:36 pm on August 2 near [[Highway 128 (California)|Highway 128]] west of Pleasants Valley Road. By sundown mandatory evacuations were ordered for Canyon Creek Campground and Golden Bear Estates.{{cite news|last1=Locke|first1=Cathy|last2=Sangree|first2=Hudson|title=Wildfire near Winters grows explosively, evacuations ordered|url=http://www.sacbee.com/news/local/crime/article93392867.html|accessdate=4 August 2016|agency=[[Sacramento Bee]]|date=2 August 2016}} The following day, less than 24 hours after the fire was first reported, it had grown to over {{convert|4000|acre|km2}}.{{cite web|last1=Rossman|first1=Randi|title='Cold' fire near Lake Berryessa now at 4,000 acres|url=http://www.sonomanews.com/home/5926725-181/cold-fire-near-lake-berryessa?artslide=0|website=Sonoma Index-Tribune|accessdate=4 August 2016}} A [[Red Cross]] shelter was briefly setup in [[Winters, California|Winters]] but was closed due to lack of use.{{cite news|last1=Rossmann|first1=Randi|title=Cold fire near Lake Berryessa now at 4,000 acres|url=http://www.pressdemocrat.com/news/5924941-181/cold-fire-in-napa-county?ref=menu&artslide=0|accessdate=4 August 2016|work=Santa Rosa Press Democrat|date=3 August 2016}} By August 4, the third day, the fire had grown to {{convert|4,700|acres|km2}}, with 903 fire personnel members on the ground and the evacuation order for Golden Bear Estates had been lifted.{{cite web|last1=Cahill|first1=Nick|title=Wildfire Near Napa Wine Country Doubles in Size|url=http://www.courthousenews.com/2016/08/04/wildfire-near-napa-wine-country-doubles-in-size.htm|website=Courthouse News Services|accessdate=4 August 2016}} By August 6, the fourth day, the fire had grown to {{convert|5,385|acres|km2}} with 1,625 fire personnel members on the ground and Highway 128 was re-opened to traffic and Thompson Valley Road at Highway 128 being closed. The fire was contained by 6 PM on August 11. The Cold Fire caused an estimated $100,000 in damaged. In total, {{convert|5,731|acres|km2}} acres had been burned and two buildings, hunting cabins, had been destroyed. The cause of the fire remains under investigation. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{California wildfires}} [[Category:2016 California wildfires]] [[Category:Wildfires in Yolo County, California]] [[Category:Vaca Mountains]] [[Category:History of Yolo County, California]] [[Category:Winters, California]] {{wildfire-stub}}

The '''Eta Carinids''' are a [[meteor shower]] lasting from January 14 to 27 each year, peaking on January 21. C. S. Nilsson of the Adelaide Observatory discovered them in 1961 in Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://meteorshowersonline.com/showers/eta_carinids.html|title=Eta Carinids|last=Kronk|first=Gary W.|publisher=Meteor Showers Online|pages=1|accessdate=2007-01-21}}</ref> Roughly two to three meteors occur per hour at its maximum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.astrosurf.com/sliop/meteor/eta%20carinids.htm|title=Eta Carinids|publisher=maa.mhn.de|pages=1|accessdate=2008-08-05}}</ref> It gets its name from the [[radiant (meteor shower)|radiant]] which is close to the nebulous star [[Eta Carinae]].
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Meteor showers]] [[Category:January events]]
{{meteoroid-stub}} {{Meteor showers}}

revision.comment: Add: jstor, website. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}}
In [[philosophy]], '''eternal oblivion''' (also referred to as '''non-existence''' or '''nothingness''')<ref name=DNS>{{cite web |url=http://www.naturalism.org/death.htm |title=Death, Nothingness, and Subjectivity |website=Naturalism.org |first=Thomas W. |last=Clark |authorlink= |publisher=Center for Naturalism |accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref><ref name="Schell Reader">{{cite book |title=The Jonathan Schell Reader: On the United States at War, the Long Crisis of the American Republic, and the Fate of the Earth |first=Jonathan |last=Schell |authorlink=Jonathan Schell |publisher=[[The Nation Institute|Nation Books]] |location = New York |date=2004 |isbn=9781560254072 |pages=}}</ref>{{page needed|date=May 2015}} is the permanent cessation of one's [[consciousness]] upon [[death]]. This concept is often associated with [[religious skepticism]] and [[atheism]],<ref name="Heath 2010">{{cite book |last1=Heath |first1=Pamela |first2=Jon |last2=Klimo |title=Handbook to the Afterlife |publisher=North Atlantic Books |location=Berkeley, CA |year=2010 |isbn=9781556438691 |page=18 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=fuKB8MPMdG4C&lpg=PA18&pg=PA18#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> and may be based in part on the lack of objective evidence for an [[afterlife]] and identifying fallacies in the arguments for an afterlife such as [[Occam's razor]].
According to contemporary theories of consciousness, the brain is the basis of [[subjectivity|subjective experience]], [[agency (philosophy)|agency]], [[self-awareness]], and [[awareness]] of the surrounding [[nature|natural world]]. When [[brain death]] occurs, all [[brain activity|brain function]] permanently ceases. Many people who believe that death is a permanent cessation of consciousness also believe that consciousness is dependent upon the functioning of the brain. Scientific research has discovered that some areas of the brain, like the [[reticular activating system]] or the [[thalamus]], appear to be [[necessity and sufficiency|necessary]] for consciousness, because [[disorders of consciousness|damage to these structures]] or their lack of function causes a loss of consciousness.
Through a naturalist analysis of the [[mind]] (an approach adopted by many philosophers of mind and neuroscientists), it is regarded as being dependent on the brain, as shown from the various effects of brain damage.<ref name="Neuroscience and the soul">{{cite web |url=http://www.patheos.com/blogs/hallq/2013/01/neuroscience-and-the-soul/ |title=Neuroscience and the Soul |last=Hallquist |first=Chris |authorlink= |date=20 January 2013 |publisher=Patheos.com |website=The Uncredible HallQ |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=14 February 2015}} Quoting neuroscientist [[Sam Harris (author)|Sam Harris]] ([https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f6iHe0ra_UM video]).</ref>
== Etymology == The English word "oblivion" (late 14c.) comes from the [[Old French]] ''oblivion'' (13c.) and directly from the [[Latin]] ''oblivionem'', meaning "forgetfulness; a being forgotten", which also comes from the word ''oblivisci'' ("to forget").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=oblivion|title=oblivion - Origin and meaning of oblivion by Online Etymology Dictionary|website=www.etymonline.com|accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref> [[:wikt:oblivion|Oblivion]] itself means "state of being forgotten".
==Oblivion and subjectivity== Thomas W. Clark, founder of Center for Naturalism, wrote a paper titled "Death, Nothingness, and Subjectivity".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.naturalism.org/death.htm |title=death |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140208055953/http://www.naturalism.org/death.htm |website=www.naturalism.org |archivedate=2014-02-08 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> He critiqued what he saw as a flawed description of eternal oblivion as a "plunge into darkness". When some imagine their deaths (including the non-religious), they project themselves into a future [[self]] which experiences an eternal silent darkness. This is wrong, because without consciousness, there is no awareness of [[space]] and no basis for [[time]]. For Clark, in oblivion there isn't even an absence of experience, as we can only speak of experience when a subjective self exists.
According to [[neuroscience|neuroscientist]] [[Giulio Tononi]], consciousness is "all we are and all we have: lose consciousness and, as far as you are concerned, your own self and the entire world dissolve into nothingness."<ref name="pmid19098144">{{cite journal |last=Tononi |first=Giulio |title=Consciousness as Integrated Information: A Provisional Manifesto |journal=The Biological Bulletin |volume=215 |issue=3 |year=2008 |pages=216–42 |pmid=19098144 |doi=10.2307/25470707 |url=http://www.biolbull.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=19098144 |issn= |accessdate=14 February 2015|jstor=25470707 }}</ref>
==Neuroscience== [[Steven Pinker]] explains the following in the seminar Is Science Killing the Soul, a discussion with [[Richard Dawkins]] presenting evidence against the existence of [[soul]]s. He elaborates;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.edge.org/conversation/richard_dawkins-steven_pinker-is-science-killing-the-soul|title=Is science killing the soul?|date=4 July 1999|first=John|last=Brockman|website=Edge|accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref> : "Many kinds of evidence show that the mind is an entity in the physical world, part of a causal chain of physical events. If you send an electric current through the brain, you cause the person to have a vivid experience. If a part of the brain dies because of a blood clot or a burst artery or a bullet wound, a part of the person is gone — the person may lose an ability to see, think, or feel in a certain way, and the entire personality may change. The same thing happens gradually when the brain accumulates a protein called beta-amyloid in the tragic disease known as [[Alzheimer's]]. The person — the soul, if you want — gradually disappears as the brain decays from this physical process. We know that every form of mental activity — every emotion, every thought, every percept — gives off electrical, magnetic, or metabolic signals that can be recorded with increasing precision by [[positron emission tomography]], [[functional magnetic resonance imaging]], [[magnetoencephalography]], and other techniques. We know that if you look at the brain under a microscope, it has a breathtaking degree of complexity — on the order of a trillion synapses — that's fully commensurate with the breathtaking complexity of human thought and experience. We know that when the brain dies, the person goes out of existence."
==Physics and death== In his book ''The Big Picture'', physicist [[Sean M. Carroll|Sean Carroll]] asserts that through physics we can demonstrate that death is equivalent to eternal oblivion. He writes;<ref>{{cite book |last=Carroll |first=Sean M. |title=The Big Picture: On the Origins of Life, Meaning, and the Universe Itself |year=2016 |publisher=Penguin |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x21qCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA218 |isbn=9780698409767 |p=218}}</ref> : "There is a much more profound implication of accepting the Core Theory as underlying the world of our everyday experience. Namely: there is no life after death. We each have a finite time as living creatures, and when it's over, it's over. The reasoning behind such a sweeping claim is even more straightforward than the argument against [[telekinesis]] or [[astrology]]. If the particles and forces of the Core Theory are what constitute each living being, without any immaterial soul, then the information that makes up "you" is contained in the arrangement of atoms that makes up your body, including your brain. There is no place for that information to go, or any way for it to be preserved, outside your body. There are no particles or fields that could store it and take it away."
== In philosophy == {{primary sources|section|date=August 2017}} In the ''[[Apology (Plato)|Apology of Socrates]]'' (written by [[Plato]]), after [[Socrates]] is sentenced to death, he addresses the court. He ponders the nature of death, and summarizes that there are basically two opinions about it. The first is that it is a [[Metempsychosis|migration of the soul]] or [[consciousness]] from this existence into another, and that the souls of all previously deceased people will also be there. This excites Socrates, because he will be able to conduct his [[Socratic method|dialectic inquiries]] with all of the great [[Greek hero cult|Greek heroes]] and thinkers of the past. The other opinion about death is that it is oblivion, the complete cessation of consciousness, not only unable to feel but a complete lack of awareness, like a person in a deep, dreamless sleep. Socrates says that even this oblivion does not frighten him very much, because while he would be unaware, he would correspondingly be free from any pain or suffering. Indeed, Socrates says, not even the great King of Persia could say that he ever rested so soundly and peacefully as he did in a dreamless sleep.
[[Cicero]], writing three centuries later in his treatise ''[[Cato Maior de Senectute|On Old Age]]'', in the voice of [[Cato the Elder]], similarly discussed the prospects of death, frequently referring to the works of earlier Greek writers. Cicero also concluded that death was either a continuation of consciousness or cessation of it, and that if consciousness continues in some form, there is no reason to fear death; while if it is in fact eternal oblivion, he will be free of all worldly miseries, in which case he should also not be deeply troubled by death.
Similar thoughts about death were expressed by the [[Roman Republic|Roman]] [[poet]] and [[Philosophy|philosopher]] [[Lucretius]] in his first-century BC [[Didacticism|didactic]] poem ''[[De rerum natura]]'' and by the ancient [[Greek philosophy|Greek philosopher]] [[Epicurus]] in his ''Letter to Menoeceus'', in which he writes;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epicurus.net/en/menoeceus.html|title=Epicurus - Letter to Menoeceus|first=Vincent|last=Cook|website=www.epicurus.net|accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.gsu.edu/~phltso/deathfrags.html|title=Epicurus and Lucretius against the dear of death|website=www2.gsu.edu|accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref> : "Accustom yourself to believing that death is nothing to us, for good and evil imply the capacity for sensation, and death is the privation of all sentience; therefore, a correct understanding that death is nothing to us makes the mortality of life enjoyable, not by adding to life a limitless time, but by taking away the yearning after immortality. For life has no terrors for him who has thoroughly understood that there are no terrors for him in ceasing to live. Foolish, therefore, is the man who says that he fears death, not because it will pain when it comes, but because it pains in the prospect. Whatever causes no annoyance when it is present causes only a groundless pain in the expectation. Death, therefore, the most awful of evils, is nothing to us, seeing that, when we are, death is not come, and when death is come, we are not. It is nothing, then, either to the living or to the dead, for with the living it is not and the dead exist no longer."
Paraphrasing philosopher [[Paul Edwards (philosopher)|Paul Edwards]], Keith Augustine and Yonatan I. Fishman note that "the greater the damage to the brain, the greater the corresponding damage to the mind. The natural extrapolation from this pattern is all too clear — obliterate brain functioning altogether, and mental functioning too will cease".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=dlRuBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA206 books.google.com], Augustine & Fishman, 2015, p. 206.</ref>
==See also== {{wikiquote|Oblivion}} * [[Annihilationism]] * [[Consciousness after death]] * [[Information-theoretic death]] * [[Neural correlates of consciousness]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *[[Michael Martin (philosopher)|Martin, Michael]]; Augustine, Keith. (2015). [https://books.google.com/books?id=dlRuBwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover ''The Myth of an Afterlife: The Case against Life After Death'']. Rowman & Littlefield. {{ISBN|978-0-8108-8677-3}}
{{death}}
[[Category:Death]] [[Category:Afterlife]]

{{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=August 2010}} {{notability|date=August 2010}} }} __NOTOC__ {{Redirect|EUDC|end-user defined characters in the Microsoft Windows environment|TrueType#File_formats}} The '''European Universities Debating Championship''' ('''EUDC''') is an annual [[debate|debating]] tournament for teams from [[university|universities]] in [[Europe]]. The competition uses the [[British Parliamentary Style|British Parliamentary Debate]] format (the same debate format used at the [[World Universities Debating Championship]]).
The championships as they are known today were first held in [[Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands]] at [[Erasmus University]] from 8–11 April 1999.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.viennaeudc.eu/abouteudc/|title=The European University Debating Championships (EUDC) - Vienna EUDC 2015|work=Vienna EUDC 2015|access-date=2018-04-05|language=en-US}}</ref> Subsequent tournaments were held at a similar time of year until Koc EUDC in 2007 when the tournament shifted to the late summer in order to accommodate all university examination periods across the continent. The competition has also become longer to accommodate the growth of the event.
The competition in 1999 involved 32 teams of two speakers, but has now grown to involve up to 200 teams each year. Institutions can enter more than one team based on the ability of the organisers to accommodate them. Some institutions also enter teams from more than one separate debating societies within their institution.
Participating teams are drawn principally from European [[tertiary education]] institutions, although teams from the [[Middle East]] and central [[Asia]]n institutions are eligible pending the formation of similar competitions in their regions. Students at the [[Inns of Court]] are also eligible subject to some conditions.
== Current Champions==
The current European Champions in the Open category are Noam Dahan and Tom Manor from [[Tel Aviv University]], Israel.
The 'English as a Second Language' category was won by Ido Kotler and Amichay Even Chen from [[Tel Aviv University]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.achteminute.de/en/20180808/eudc-2018-results-tel-aviv-win-both-finals/|title=EUDC 2018 Results: Tel Aviv win both finals|date=2018-08-08|work=Achte Minute|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-US}}</ref>.
== Championships ==
These are the institutions (universities or debating bodies) that have hosted or will host the European Universities Debating Championships.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! 2015|access-date=2018-05-28|language=en-US}}</ref> |- |2016 |{{flagicon|POL}} Warsaw (Fundacja Polska Debatuje) |- |2017 |{{flagicon|EST}} Tallinn University of Technology Debate Society<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.novisadeudc.com/|title=Novi Sad EUDC 2018|website=www.novisadeudc.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref> |- |2019 |{{flagicon|GRE}} Debating Society of Greece<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://athenseudc.com/|title=Athens EUDC 2019|website=athenseudc.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref> |- |2020 |{{Flagicon|Kazakhstan}} Astana Debate Union <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://astanaeudc.com|title=Astana EUDC 2020|website=astanaeudc.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-10}}</ref> |}
== EUDC Council and EUDC Committee ==
In 1999, the EUDC Council was formed as the highest decision making organ. Every competing nation has one vote. The council sits during the tournament. It decides on the constitution, criteria regarding eligibility issues, and about the hosts of future championships.
The EUDC Committee consist of a president, who also chairs the council, a secretary, a registrar, the hosts of the current tournament and the past tournament and regional representatives for central and eastern Europe, for Northern and Western Europe, South-East Europe, the middle east and the Islands of the North Atlantic.
Minutes of EUDC Council and the Constitution are published on the EUDC Council Website<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eudc.wikidot.com/documents|title=Constitution and Minutes - EUDC Council|website=eudc.wikidot.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref>
The current chair of council and president of the committee is Jan-Gunther Gosselke from the [[Debattierclub St Gallen]] from [[Switzerland]].
== See also == * [[World Universities Debating Championship]]
==References== <references/>

{{Refimprove|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = <!--Uses page name if omitted--> | native_name = | logo = <!--INCLUDE "[[File:Filename.ext]]" when entering file name--> | logo_caption = | image = <!--DO NOT include "File:" part of image name (different from above because of merger with Template:Infobox festival)--> | imagesize = | caption = | date = <!--"dates=" also works, as merged from Template:Infobox festival. Do not use both--> | begins = | ends = | prev = | next = | frequency = Annual | location = [[Grand Falls-Windsor]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador]], [[Canada]] | years_active = 1985-present | first = <!--"founded=" also works--> | last = | participants = | attendance = | genre = [[Food festival]] | budget = | patron = | organised = <!--"organized=" also works--> | website = http://www.evsalmonfestival.com/ | footnotes = }} The '''Exploits Valley Salmon Festival''' is an annual festival held in [[Grand Falls-Windsor]] of the [[Exploits Valley]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador]], [[Canada]] that dates back to 1985.<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=[[The Telegram]]|author=Corrina Baggs|title=A river runs through it|date=July 10, 2009|url=http://www.thetelegram.com/Food/2009-07-10/article-1440484/A-river-runs-through-it/1|accessdate=December 31, 2012}}</ref> Events that are part of the festival include a dance in a stadium and a dinner of [[salmon]].<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=[[The Telegram]]|title=Remaining events for salmon festival announced|date=June 24, 2010|url=http://www.thetelegram.com/Festivals-events/2010-06-24/article-1451652/Remaining-events-for-salmon-festival-announced/1|accessdate=December 31, 2012}}</ref> There is also a concert, although the concert in 2007 was so poorly attended that the organisers lost $200,000 on it.<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=The Advertiser|author=Wendy Houlihan|title=Festival success stands test of time|date=December 13, 2007|url=http://www.gfwadvertiser.ca/Editorial-opinion/2007-12-13/article-1407132/Festival-success-stands-test-of-time/1|accessdate=December 31, 2012}}</ref> The organisers continued to lose money on the festival in 2008, 2009,<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=The Advertiser|author=Sue Hickey|title=More than the money|date=November 23, 2009|url=http://www.gfwadvertiser.ca/Editorial-opinion/2009-11-23/article-1405149/More-than-the-money/1|accessdate=December 31, 2012}}</ref> and 2010.<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=The Advertiser|author=Krysta Carroll|title='It is still a deficit'|date=October 4, 2010|url=http://www.gfwadvertiser.ca/News/2010-10-04/article-1818785/It-is-still-a-deficit/2|accessdate=December 31, 2012}}</ref> Businessman Boyd Cohen was the [[Patronage|patron]] of the 2009 festival.<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=The Advertiser|author=Corrina Baggs|title=Local business icon named festival patron|date=July 16, 2009|url=http://www.gfwadvertiser.ca/News/2009-07-16/article-1405772/Local-business-icon-named-festival-patron/1|accessdate=December 31, 2012}}</ref> The main festival concert in 2010 featured Matthew Hornell and the Diamond Minds.<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=The Advertiser|author=Krysta Carroll|title=Hitting the big stage|date=July 15, 2010|url=http://www.gfwadvertiser.ca/News/2010-07-15/article-1568691/Hitting-the-big-stage/1|accessdate=December 31, 2012}}</ref> There was also a [[Gospel music|gospel]] concert that was attended by hundreds of people. [[Kellie Loder]], [[Starfield (band)|Starfield]], and Reverend Roy Martin performed at this concert.<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=The Advertiser|author=Kent Burton|title=Annual event comes to a close|date=July 22, 2010|url=http://www.gfwadvertiser.ca/News/2010-07-22/article-1601765/Annual-event-comes-to-a-close/2|accessdate=December 8, 2012}}</ref> In 2012, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' named the festival one of the top ten attractions for British [[foodie]]s [[vacation]]ing in [[Canada]].<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|title=Canadian holidays: dining guide for food lovers|date=March 2, 2012|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sponsored/travel/summer-holidays-canada/9099005/Canada-food-and-drink-dining-guide.html|accessdate=December 31, 2012}}</ref> In 2011, The town signed a deal with concert promoters RFO. As a result, the festival experienced a resurgence attracting larger crowds, The shows were headlined by popular groups such as [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]], [[Smash Mouth]] and [[Down with Webster]] in 2011, [[Aerosmith]] & [[Flo Rida]] in 2012, [[The Eagles]] and [[The Tragically Hip]] in 2013, [[Maroon 5]] in 2014 and [[John Fogerty]], [[Tom Cochrane]], [[America (band)|America]] and [[The Fables]] (making their first public performance in 12 years) in 2015.
The 2013 concert headlined by The Eagles was panned by critics for the poor planning. The temperature rose to approximately 30 degrees Celsius and many concert goers complained in regards to lack of available water as patrons were not permitted to bring their own. (concession stands reportedly ran out twice). according to reports more than 100 people had to be treated for dehydration. VIP ticket holders complained too many tickets were sold for the private section on the field and made the concert unenjoyable. Such complainants had told media outlets they were considering a class action lawsuit but it never materialized.
The 2014 concert achieved controversy during the planning stages. The town frequently delayed making an official announcement in regards to who would headline the show. Mayor Al Hawkins appeared on local radio commenting that the date would not be changed from a planned July 9th date. But despite this only a week later the concert was officially announced to take place on July 16th and would be headlined by Maroon 5. Many complained about the date change and were unimpressed with the lineup, expecting a more "legendary" act as in the past 3 years and cited lack of variety of types of music. as a result attendance was only 8,500 (less than 1/3 of the previous year) and the town reported a near $500,000 loss. the town denied any belief the date change lead to a low turnout instead blaming it on the media backlash from the previous year.
In 2015, The town opted to buy out of their contract with RFO in response to the previous year's disappointment. The salmon festival success was threatened however, when the city of St. John's announced the date of their Confederation concert headlined by the legendary [[Rod Stewart]] would take place on the same date as the salmon festival concert. The own attempted to compete by announcing the salmon festival would headlined by [[John Fogerty]] and would feature [[Tom Cochrane]], [[America (band)|America]] and The Fables. Also, organizers allowed patrons to leave the grounds and return later (via a bracelet system) until 7pm. Despite rave reviews the concert was attended by only 5,500 people and a $667,000 loss. Later reports revealed promoters had advised the town to cancel the concert beforehand due to early tickets sales being poor but the decision to go ahead was narrowly passed by town council. reports also said John Fogerty had been paid $655,000 to perform at the show while Tom Cochrane and The Fables were paid a meager (by comparison) $52,000 and $10,000 respectively.
The over $1 million in losses collectively over the previous 2 years lead to questions over the future of the yearly event. however, council announced the 2016 concert would go ahead but that it would be the end of the "mega concert". They would later announce a lineup consisting of headliner [[Trooper (band)|Trooper]] as well as [[The Stampeders]] and Newfoundland favorite [[Buddy Wasisname and the Other Fellers]]. the rest of the lineup consisting of local bands. ==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Music festivals in Newfoundland and Labrador]] [[Category:Grand Falls-Windsor]] [[Category:Salmon]] [[Category:Food and drink festivals in Canada]] [[Category:1985 establishments in Canada]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1985]] [[Category:Seafood festivals]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox event | title = Faith Hedgepeth homicide | image = Faith Hedgepth.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | image_alt = A smiling, dark-eyed, olive-skinned young woman with wavy dark brown hair that goes down to bust level, wearing a sleeveless light beige top and some golden jewelry at the cleavage level | caption = Faith Hedgepeth | time = Between 4:25 and 11 a.m. | duration = | date = {{start date|2012|09|07}} | venue = | location = [[Chapel Hill, North Carolina]], U.S. | coordinates = {{coord|35.94128|-79.00266|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} | motive = | burial = [[Warrenton, North Carolina]] }} The body of '''Faith Hedgepeth''' (born September 26, 1992), an undergraduate student in her third year at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] (UNCCH), was found in her apartment by a friend on the morning of September 7, 2012. She had been beaten over the head with a blunt instrument, later found to be an empty liquor bottle, and very likely raped. The last time she was known for certain to be alive was much earlier that morning, when she went to bed after returning from a local nightclub with her roommate.<ref name="ABC News story">{{cite news|last1=Lopez|first1=Ed|last2=Valiente|first2=Alexa|title=Murdered UNC Student's Final Moments: What Police Say Happened to Faith Hedgepeth|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/murdered-unc-students-final-moments-police-happened-faith/story?id=42281581|newspaper=[[ABC News]]|date=September 22, 2016|accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref>
Police have recovered considerable [[forensic evidence]] in the case, but so far it has served to eliminate one likely suspect, a former boyfriend of her roommate who reportedly expressed anger and resentment toward Hedgepeth, even supposedly threatening to kill her if he could not reunite with her roommate. His [[DNA]], however, did not match that left at the scene. A note left at the scene, suggesting the writer was jealous, is also believed to have been written by the killer; it was among a large group of documents released by police two years after the crime, following a court action brought by several local media outlets.<ref name="WRAL documents release story">{{cite news|title=Newly released docs detail police's case in UNC student's murder|url=http://www.wral.com/newly-released-docs-detail-police-s-case-in-unc-student-s-murder/13954237/|newspaper=[[WRAL-TV]]|date=September 26, 2016|accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref>
Four years after the killing, a Virginia DNA testing company prepared and released, at police's behest, an image showing what the suspect might look like based on his genetic [[phenotype]].<ref name="DNA phenotyping story">{{cite news|last1=Fuerte|first1=Stephanie|last2=Valiente|first2=Alexa|title=Police Release Facial Image They Say Could Help Identify Murdered UNC Student's Killer|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/police-release-facial-image-identify-murdered-unc-students/story?id=42312443|newspaper=[[ABC News]]|date=September 23, 2016|accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref> A voicemail possibly accidentally recorded by Hedgepeth may also capture some of the events that led to her death. The [[Chapel Hill, North Carolina|Chapel Hill]] police continue to investigate.
==Background==
A member of the [[Haliwa-Saponi]] [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American tribe]] recognized by the state of [[North Carolina]], Faith Hedgepeth was born in 1992 in [[Warren County, North Carolina|Warren County]], part of the tribe's traditional territory. Her parents divorced within a year of her birth, and she was raised by her mother, with help from an older sister, in [[Hollister, North Carolina|Hollister]] and [[Warrenton, North Carolina|Warrenton]]. Connie Hedgepeth named her third daughter [[Faith (name)|Faith]] because she believed that was what she needed to raise a fourth child when she already had two sons and a daughter and a husband with a drug problem.<ref name="Indian Country three-year anniversary story">{{cite news|last=Landry|first=Alyssa|title=Three Years Later: Still No Answers for Murdered Native Student’s Family|url=https://indiancountrymedianetwork.com/news/native-news/three-years-later-still-no-answers-for-murdered-native-students-family/|newspaper=[[Indian Country Media Network]]|date=September 9, 2015|accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref>
In high school, Hedgepeth was an honor student, a cheerleader and a member of many extracurricular clubs and organizations. She did well enough academically to earn a [[Gates Millennium Scholars|Gates Millennium Scholarship]] to attend the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]]. Her father had attended UNCCH as well, but dropped out; she hoped to be the first in her family to graduate from college. After that, she was considering further studies to become either a [[pediatrics|pediatrician]] or teacher.<ref name="Indian Country three-year anniversary story" />
Her first two years at the university went well for her; although she took the spring 2012 semester off.<ref name="Daily Tarheel timeline story">{{cite news|last=Dulaney|first=Chelsea|title=On the last night of her life, an uncertain timeline for Faith Danielle Hedgepeth|url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2012/10/on-last-night-an-uncertain-timeline|newspaper=[[The Daily Tar Heel]]|date=October 25, 2012|accessdate=September 5, 2017}}</ref> She remained in the [[Chapel Hill, North Carolina|Chapel Hill]] area over the summer, living in an off-campus apartment at the Hawthorne at the View complex between Chapel Hill and [[Durham, North Carolina|Durham]], on the line between [[Durham County, North Carolina|Durham]] and [[Orange County, North Carolina|Orange]] counties, during the month of August; she planned to move to another apartment after her [[Student financial aid (United States)|financial aid]] for the fall semester was made available to her. She shared the apartment with Karena Rosario, whom she had been friends with since freshman year,<ref name="Daily Tarheel timeline story" /> and Rosario's boyfriend, Eriq Takoy Jones.<ref name="N&O documents release story">{{cite news|last=Blythe|first=Anne|title=Court documents unsealed in search for Faith Hedgepeth's killer|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/local/crime/article10051073.html|newspaper=[[The News & Observer]]|date=September 5, 2014|accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref>
The relationship between Jones and Rosario had been marked by [[domestic violence]], and eventually she ended it and he moved out. However, he had in early July 2012 twice attempted to break into the apartment, even after Rosario changed the locks. Hedgepeth drove her roommate to court to get a [[Injunction|protective order]] that required Jones to stay away from the apartment.<ref name="Daily Tarheel timeline story" /> Jones reportedly resented Hedgepeth's influence over his former girlfriend, and at one point reportedly threatened during a phone conversation with Hedgepeth to kill her if he could not get back together with Rosario.<ref name="N&O documents release story" />
==Homicide==
The evening of September 6, 2012, a Thursday, began at 5:45 p.m. with Hedgepeth attending a rush event for the campus chapter of [[Alpha Pi Omega]], a historically Native American [[sorority]] she hoped to join. At 7:15 she left, saying she had to work on a paper she was writing about the history of her tribe. She and Rosario went to the university's [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill#Libraries|Davis Library]] to study together at 8 p.m. Between 8:30 and 9 she exchanged texts with her father about her hopes to join the sorority.<ref name="Daily Tarheel timeline story" />
Hedgepeth left Rosario there briefly and returned around 11:30, after which they returned to their apartment together, arriving there around midnight. A half-hour later they left again, heading for Thrill, a nightclub in downtown Chapel Hill which admitted customers under the legal drinking age of 21 to dance. The two young women arrived at Thrill around 12:40 a.m. After almost an hour and a half of dancing, Rosario told police later that she was having an upset stomach and wanted to leave. [[Security camera]]s at the club show she and Hedgepeth leaving at 2:06 a.m.; it is the last visual record of her presence anywhere before the killing.<ref name="ABC News story" />
By 3 a.m. Hedgepeth and Rosario had returned to their apartment. A woman who lived below the two and was awake watching television said that she heard three thumping noises, which she described as similar to a heavy bag being dropped or furniture being overturned, shortly afterward. Hedgepeth's [[Facebook]] page was also accessed around the same time.<ref name="ABC News story" />
At 3:40 a.m., a text was sent from Hedgepeth's phone to that of Brandon Edwards, a former boyfriend of hers, saying "Hey b. Can you come over here please. Rosario needs you more aha. You know. Please let her know you care." Three minutes later, another text was sent from Hedgepeth's phone to Edwards' with the single word "than", believed to be a correction for the "aha" in the previous text. That was the last evidence of activity from her phone; at 4:16 Edwards sent a return text asking who the previous text was from.<ref name="N&O documents release story" />
Rosario's phone records show she was also trying to call Edwards around the same time. He did not answer, and when he did not she tried to call [[Jordan McCrary]], a [[North Carolina Tar Heels men's soccer|UNCCH soccer player]] she knew. At 4:25 a.m., she left the apartment to get in McCrary's car. At that time, Rosario said later, she believed Hedgepeth was asleep in her room, and left the apartment's door unlocked.<ref name="ABC News story" />
McCrary drove Rosario to the home of another acquaintance on West Longview Street in Chapel Hill. She put the time of her arrival there at around 4:30 a.m. After spending the rest of the night and the early morning there, a short time after 10:30 she began trying to arrange a ride home. After attempting to reach Hedgepeth, who did not answer, Rosario instead called another friend, Marisol Rangel, who came and took her back to her apartment.<ref name="ABC News story" />
When they arrived there, shortly before 11 a.m., they entered and called for Hedgepeth, who did not respond. In her bedroom, they found her bloodied body, wrapped in a quilt, partially nude. They immediately dialed [[9-1-1]] and informed police.<ref name="ABC News story" />
==Investigation==
Details of the investigation were not discussed publicly at first, a deviation from the Chapel Hill police's usual practice;<ref name="Dulaney Atavist piece">{{cite news|last=Dulaney|first=Chelsea|title=In the Shadow of the Sealings|url=https://synapse.atavist.com/sealings|newspaper=[[Atavist]]|date=April 2014|accessdate=September 7, 2017}}</ref> the town obtained a court order sealing all records as they were collected.<ref name="Daily Tarheel timeline story" /> Police collected [[semen]] from the scene and used it to develop a DNA profile; it reportedly was consistent with male DNA found elsewhere in the apartment. The autopsy determined that Hedgepeth had died from [[blunt force trauma]] to the head, likely a result of being hit by an empty rum bottle in the apartment.<ref name="ABC News story" />
Jones seemed to be a very strong suspect from the beginning. Police learned of his history of domestic violence and his threat against Hedgepeth. They also found that the night before, around 6 p.m., he had texted an acquaintance asking for forgiveness "for what I am about to do" and then posted the same message on his [[Twitter]] feed. Three days later, he changed the banner on his [[Facebook]] page to read "Dear Lord, Forgive me for all of my sins and the sins I may commit today. Protect me from the girls who don't deserve me and the ones who wish me dead today."<ref name="N&O documents release story" />
Police sought a DNA sample from Jones, who they considered a [[person of interest]]; after some initial resistance, he complied. It did not match the one from the apartment, and they excluded him as a suspect. DNA from Edwards and many other men who police found had been at Thrill during the same time as Rosario and Hedgepeth was also tested, with the same result.<ref name="Crime Watch Daily">{{cite news|title=Crime Watch Daily investigates the murder of Faith Hedgepeth|url=https://crimewatchdaily.com/2016/02/16/crime-watch-daily-investigates-the-murder-of-faith-hedgepeth/|newspaper=[[Crime Watch Daily]]|date=February 16, 2016|accessdate=September 5, 2017}}</ref>
Within days the university's board of trustees, the local [[Crime Stoppers]] chapter, the [[Haliwa-Saponi]] tribe and the apartment complex had offered a combined $29,000 in reward money for information leading to an arrest. Police hoped the reward money would lead to a quick resolution of the case, as their resources were limited. In the 2008 [[murder of Eve Carson]], at the time UNCCH's undergraduate student body president, a $25,000 reward had led to the killers' arrest.<ref name="Daily Tarheel reward story">{{cite news|last=Dulaney|first=Chelsea|title=Trustees offer $25,000 in homicide case|url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2012/09/trustees-offer-25000-in-homicide-case|newspaper=[[The Daily Tar Heel]]|date=September 12, 2012|accessdate=September 5, 2017}}</ref> Two months later the office of [[Governor of North Carolina|governor]] [[Bev Perdue]] added another $10,000 to the reward for Hedgepeth's killer.<ref name="Daily Tarheel governor's reward story">{{cite news|last=Dulaney|first=Chelsea|title=Reward raised for information in Hedgepeth slaying|url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2012/11/reward-upped-in-student-slaying|newspaper=[[The Daily Tar Heel]]|date=November 14, 2012|accessdate=September 5, 2017}}</ref>
===Seal on case records===
In November, ''[[The Daily Tar Heel]]'', UNCCH's student newspaper, petitioned the judge who had ordered the investigation records sealed to release an early search warrant in the case. Instead the judge ordered it resealed for another 45 days. At that time the Chapel Hill police had not even released Hedgepeth's cause of death, although her parents told the media that their daughter's [[death certificate]] said she had been beaten.<ref name="Daily Tarheel warrant reseal story">{{cite news|last=Dulaney|first=Chelsea|title=Still no answers in Hedgepeth killing|url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2012/12/still-no-answers-in-hedgepeth-killing|newspaper=[[The Daily Tar Heel]]|date=December 5, 2012|accessdate=September 5, 2017}}</ref>
Police announced in January that the DNA from the scene had come back as belonging to a male. From the crime scene and other evidence the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) had developed a [[Offender profiling|profile]] of the man. They said it was likely that he had lived near Hedgepeth in the past, had expressed an interest in her and his behavior may have changed since the crime, including showing an unusual interest in the case. Notwithstanding this release of information, the town successfully petitioned the court to keep the warrants under seal, saying that phase of the investigation was still not complete;<ref name="Daily Tarheel profile story">{{cite news|last=Dulaney|first=Chelsea|title=Police profile male suspect in Hedgepeth homicide|url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2013/01/50ececd570553|newspaper=[[The Daily Tar Heel]]|date=January 8, 2013|accessdate=September 5, 2017}}</ref> in May 2013 the court extended the seal another 60 days.<ref name="Daily Tarheel May 2013 seal extension story">{{cite news|last=Greene|first=Taylor|title=Hedgepeth search warrants resealed by judge|url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2013/05/hedgepeth-search-warrants-resealed-by-judge|newspaper=[[The Daily Tar Heel]]|date=May 22, 2013|accessdate=September 5, 2017}}</ref>
In September 2013, a year after the killing, Chapel Hill police formally requested the assistance of the [[North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation]], which had provided some help earlier in the investigation, with the case. "We're working the case hard, and we've used all the possible resources", said Chief Chris Blue. However, he would not share any more information about the case.<ref name="Daily Tarheel SBI story">{{cite news|last=Surane|first=Jenny|title=Faith Hedgepeth case to get new SBI help|url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2013/10/police-request-additional-assistance-in-hedgepeth-homicide|newspaper=[[The Daily Tar Heel]]|date=October 2, 2013|accessdate=September 5, 2017}}</ref>
Two months later, the ''Tar Heel'' noted that the Hedgepeth case remained open, along with the death of David Shannon, a UNCCH freshman whose body had been found on the grounds of a [[Carrboro, North Carolina|Carrboro]] cement plant the previous October 27 (while he had died from a fall, the autopsy found he was severely intoxicated, and the Carrboro police suspected [[Hazing in Greek letter organizations|hazing]] and believed there might be other students who could tell them more about the circumstances of Shannon's death). In Hedgepeth's case, there had been no new information about a possible suspect since January. Yet the case records remained under court-ordered seal.<ref name="Daily Tarheel December 2013 story">{{cite news|last=Surane|first=Jenny|title=Faith Hedgepeth case to get new SBI help|url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2013/12/yir-student-deaths|newspaper=[[The Daily Tar Heel]]|date=December 3, 2013|accessdate=September 5, 2017}}</ref>
In March 2014 the ''Tar Heel'' was joined by the [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]] ''[[The News & Observer|News & Observer]]'' and [[Capitol Broadcasting Company]], which owns three television and radio stations in the [[Research Triangle]] area, in opposing the district attorney's motion to extend the seal another 60 days. They argued that the order was not justified by a [[compelling interest]] on the state's part, and that some of the orders had been issued before the records covered by them had been created, meaning the argument for sealing them was speculative.<ref name="Daily Tarheel media companies story">{{cite news|last=Surane|first=Jenny|title=Faith Hedgepeth records to be reviewed on March 17|url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2014/03/hedgepeth-records-to-be-reviewed-on-march-17|newspaper=[[The Daily Tar Heel]]|date=March 16, 2014|accessdate=September 6, 2017}}</ref> During a hearing on the motion, the district attorney filed a more specific accounting of what investigative work had been done, allowing the media to report for the first time on what police had searched in the immediate aftermath of the crime. "Eighteen months goes by and no one's been charged and no one's been arrested" said a lawyer for the ''Tar Heel''. "The public has the right to assume the trail has gone cold, or it's not being investigated in a diligent manner." In response the district attorney's office argued that releasing the detailed records at that point would definitely hinder the investigation, and the records remained under seal.<ref name="Daily Tarheel what was searched story">{{cite news|last=Surane|first=Jenny|title=Faith Hedgepeth records to stay sealed |url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2014/03/faith-hedgepeth-records-to-stay-stealed|newspaper=[[The Daily Tar Heel]]|date=March 19, 2014|accessdate=September 6, 2017}}</ref>
====Criticism of seal====
The following month, Chelsea Dulaney, a reporter who had originally covered the case at the ''Tar Heel'', wrote an article on the ''[[Atavist]]'' platform taking a skeptical look at the sealing. She speculated that the seal's real purpose was to conceal early missteps by the Chapel Hill police, who might also not have been competent enough to handle the investigation all by themselves. The town's court filings, she noted, revealed that after the first two months of the investigation no new search warrants had been sought. "We have to ask, how hot is it?" asked one of the lawyers representing the media.<ref name="Dulaney Atavist piece" />
Dulaney talked to the residents of the apartments at Hawthorne at the View who lived near Hedgepeth and Rosario. They told her that during the preceding summer, they strongly suspected the [[domestic violence]] later reported between Rosario and Jones; they thought the police presence on the day the body was found was related to that until they learned otherwise.<ref name="Dulaney Atavist piece" />
Two of the neighbors told Dulaney that while the police sealed off the four-unit block where Hedgepeth and Rosario lived with [[Barricade tape|crime scene tape]], they only searched the women's apartment and not any of the others in it. Nor did they search the woods behind the apartments, and they only returned later to search one other apartment in the complex. They did not seem to [[canvassing|canvass]] the area, either, never knocking on doors and asking residents what they might have seen. The police also left Hedgepeth's car unsecured while they searched the apartments.<ref name="Dulaney Atavist piece" />
When the [[North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation|State Bureau of Investigation]] officers began investigating the case late in 2013, they also interviewed residents of Hawthorne at the View. One resident who spoke to Dulaney said it was clear to her that the SBI investigators were better trained than their Chapel Hill counterparts had been. The agent who interviewed her asked questions that elicited more useful information from her, she recalled.<ref name="Dulaney Atavist piece" />
In downtown Chapel Hill, Dulaney talked to the owner of a towing service who had the contract for the Thrill's parking lot. He had set up a system of [[security camera]]s to monitor activity in the club's parking lot that might have possibly recorded anything that happened outside of the club involving Hedgepeth and Rosario while they were there that morning, or after they left. The police did not ask to see it until shortly before Dulaney wrote the article, almost 19 months after the crime. By that time, he told her, any footage from that night had been long since recorded over.<ref name="Dulaney Atavist piece" />
====Release of records====
The court ordered the records unsealed in July 2014. The media organizations were able to review and report on the search warrant applications and the investigative notes that had supported them, with most names [[Sanitization (classified information)|redacted]], for not only the residences and cars but Hedgepeth's phone, computer, Facebook records and bank account. Also released was the transcript of Rosario's 9-1-1 call, and the content of the early-morning text messages as well as the timeline of Rosario and Hedgepeth's actions the night before the body was found.<ref name="N&O documents release story" />
In September 2014, almost two years after Hedgepeth's death, the [[autopsy]] report was released. It confirmed what was on her death certificate, that she had died of blunt force trauma to the head. She had numerous cuts and bruises as well as blood under her fingernails, suggesting she had struggled with her killer. The DNA taken from the semen was matched to DNA elsewhere at the scene.<ref name="N&O documents release story" />
==Evidence==
The released records included the recording of Rosario's 9-1-1 call and two pieces of evidence that were seen as potentially helpful in narrowing down the killer's identity.<ref name="N&O documents release story" /> The DNA profile was also used later to generate an image of the potential suspect.<ref name="DNA phenotyping story" /> "Investigators have excellent evidence in this case," Chief Blue said when the documents were released. "This is not a cold case. It has been and remains an active investigation."<ref name="N&O documents release story" />
===9-1-1 call===
''News & Observer'' reporter Tom Gasparoli, who covered the case extensively for his newspaper, has also devoted most of his own [[blog]] to pondering the evidence and keeping the case alive. To him, Rosario's call raised many questions.<ref name="Gaspo 9-1-1 call blog post">{{cite news|last=Gasparoli|first=Tom|title=The 911 Call Transcript is Here|url=http://www.gaspowrites.com/2014/07/the-911-call-transcript-is-here.html|newspaper=Gaspo Writes|date=July 7, 2014|accessdate=September 7, 2017}}</ref> "To me, the whole call reeks of unusual," he wrote in 2017 on the case's fifth anniversary.<ref name="Gaspo fifth anniversary blog post">{{cite news|last=Gasparoli|first=Tom|title=Five Years Ago, It Happened—New Info from Law Enforcement, Clip of Rosario 911 Call and Investigative Journey|url=http://www.gaspowrites.com/2017/09/new-info-from-law-enforcement-clip-of.html|newspaper=Gaspo Writes|date=September 6, 2017|accessdate=September 7, 2017}}</ref>
Gasparoli raised the possibility that Rosario's friend Marisol Rangel, whose voice sounds to him more like the constantly sobbing caller, was the real caller, only later identifying herself as Rosario after repeated requests from the dispatcher for her name. And if it was Rosario, she never mentions that Rangel accompanied her to the apartment. The caller also does not mention Hedgepeth's name in a call that lasts nearly eight minutes, only describing the body she has come upon as "her friend."<ref name="Gaspo fifth anniversary blog post" />
And why, Gasparoli asked, does the caller seem reluctant to touch Hedgepeth's body despite repeated pleas from the dispatcher to at least see if she is still breathing? If Rosario was not able to bring herself to do so, could she not have asked Rangel to do so? "I have often thought," Gaparoli wrote,"[that] if it was [Rosario], that she didn't call 9-1-1 the moment she first saw [Hedgepeth]."<ref name="Gaspo fifth anniversary blog post" />
===Note left at scene=== [[File:Hedgepeth note.jpeg|thumb|right|The note found near the body|alt=A wrinkled piece of white paper with the words "I'm not stupid bitch jealous" scrawled on them in ballpoint pen]] Among the evidence collected was a note left near Hedgepeth's body with the text: {{quote|<center>I'M NOT STUPID<br>BITCH<br>JEALOUS}} It was sloppily written in ballpoint pen on what was determined to be the torn-off bottom of a white paper bag of the type commonly used for [[carry-out]] food. Police believe the bag may have come from Time-Out, a popular 24-hour restaurant in Chapel Hill that would have been the only place open<ref name="Time-Out website">{{cite web|title=Time-Out Grill|url=http://timeout247.com/|accessdate=September 6, 2017}}</ref> at the time Hedgepeth and Rosario left Thrill. It uses such bags and is a short distance away from the nightclub.<ref name="ABC News story" />
Investigators have not said whether they have had the handwriting analyzed. The website ''[[Crime Watch Daily]]'' had an expert, Peggy Walla, look at photos of the note. She noted that it was clean of the blood reportedly found splattered all over the room, suggesting it was written either away from the crime scene or beforehand. The writer may have been using their non-dominant hand in an attempt to disguise their handwriting. Walla believes the writer was particularly agitated, likely to the point of homicidal rage, by being called "stupid".<ref name="Crime Watch Daily" />
In his fifth-anniversary post, Gasparoli said a law enforcement source he talked to about the case refused to comment on whether the note was "odd" even as the source answered other questions. He elaborates that the words may have been intended to be read in a different order, producing wording that makes more sense ("I'm not jealous ... stupid bitch", for instance). In addition he theorizes that more than one writer may have been involved, or that not all of it may have been written at the same time.<ref name="Gaspo fifth anniversary blog post" />
"Stupid", especially, looks to Gasparoli as if it might have been written separately from the other words, as it is written much more clearly and off to the side. The [[swash (typography)|swash]] extending leftward from the [[Counter (typography)|counter]] on the "P" in "STUPID", struck him as unusually distinctive. "[It] looks quite different, much more precise than any other letter in the note," he says. It seems to Gasparoli to suggest a female writer, or at least one calmer and more intelligent than the lettering elsewhere on the note.<ref name="Gaspo fifth anniversary blog post" />
Gasparoli questioned in fact what purpose would be served by leaving it there. As a message to Hedgepeth it made no sense to leave it next to her body if she was dead; if it was written by the killer or killers it could have been particularly incriminating evidence and they had to be aware of that possibility. It looked to him, in fact, "[a]lmost as if it were a [[red herring]] ... left for some other reason than to reflect the real feelings of the killer(s). Left ... to confuse."<ref name="Gaspo fifth anniversary blog post" />
===Conversation accidentally recorded===
A friend of Hedgepeth's shared with police a long conversation, perhaps inadvertently recorded, when Hedgepeth's phone [[Pocket dialing|pocket-dialed]] them on the night before the murder, that may have some bearing on the case. It consists of a three-way conversation, three minutes long, between what appears to be Hedgepeth and a male and female, with music in the background. It was [[timestamp]]ed at 1:23 a.m., when the timeline of that night has her at the Thrill.<ref name="Crime Watch Daily" />
It was seen as mostly inaudible and of minimal evidentiary value until ''Crime Watch Daily'' hired audio expert [[Arlo West]], who specializes in enhancing such recordings. He claimed he heard Hedgepeth crying for help while the male says "I think she's dying" and the female says "Do it anyhow" after a long discussion in which the female seems to get angrier. The male and female use the name "Eric" and "Rosie" respectively.<ref name="Crime Watch Daily" /> Hedgepeth's father is convinced what was recorded was of his daughter's death; West agrees.<ref name="Indian Country voicemail story">{{cite news|last=Landry|first=Alyssa|title=Chilling Voicemail in Hedgepeth Murder Case Made Public|url=https://indiancountrymedianetwork.com/news/native-news/chilling-voicemail-in-hedgepeth-murder-case-made-public/|newspaper=[[Indian Country Media Network]]|date=March 1, 2016|accessdate=September 7, 2017}}</ref>
The website informed the Chapel Hill police of West's findings, and they agreed to consider West's enhanced version and evaluate it. However, due to the time of the message they do not believe it to be a recording of the killing; the music in the background further suggests it was recorded at Thrill.<ref name="N&O voicemail story">{{cite news|last=Schultz|first=Mark|title=Expert, police dispute voicemail in Faith Hedgepeth case|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/local/community/chapel-hill-news/article61107117.html|newspaper=[[The News & Observer]]|date=February 20, 2016|accessdate=September 7, 2017}}</ref> Several months later they added that the [[metadata]] associated with the call reinforces this belief.<ref name="N&O fourth anniversary story">{{cite news|last=Gasparoli|first=Tom|title=Chapel Hill police say UNC student's murder not cold case|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/local/community/durham-news/dn-opinion/article95292287.html|newspaper=[[The News & Observer]]|date=August 17, 2016|accessdate=September 8, 2017}}</ref>
West, for his part, cites a known software issue with phones like Hedgepeth's that resulted in inaccurate timestamps. He discounts the background sound as being music, since his analysis did not produce any sounds like percussion, a heavy bass or synthesizers. Further, he adds, there are none of the background sounds, like glasses clinking and others talking, that one would associate with a nightclub.<ref name="N&O voicemail story" />
===Image of suspect generated from DNA profile===
On a September 23, 2016, episode of the [[ABC News]] program ''[[20/20 (U.S. TV series)|20/20]]'', Chapel Hill police released an image generated by Parabon NanoLabs, a genetic testing company in [[Reston, Virginia]], of what the suspect who left the semen might look like based purely on the [[phenotype]] in his DNA profile.<ref name="DNA phenotyping story" /> Parabon's president told ABC that Snapshot, the program his company used to create the image, "predicts eye color, hair color, skin color, freckling, face morphology and ancestry." The image included a chart listing the probability that the suspect had the traits he was assigned.<ref name="DNA phenotyping story" />
According to the image, the suspect was "very strongly Native American and European mixed ancestry or Latino". Most of his [[genetic marker]]s pointed to [[Mexican American|Mexican]], [[Colombian American|Colombian]] and [[Iberian peninsula|Iberian]] ancestry, with some other South American and African countries making up the balance. Parabon believed with over 80% confidence that the suspect would have a skin tone in the [[Olive skin|olive]] range, with very few freckles or none at all and black hair. It did not make any predictions as to his height and weight.<ref name="DNA phenotyping story" />
==Theories==
Chapel Hill police have not named any suspects or even [[person of interest|persons of interest]] in the case, but have stated that they do not believe the killing was a mere [[crime of opportunity]] by a stranger, that instead it was committed by someone in her [[social group]], likely someone who knew her through UNCCH. They are certain the killer or killers knew Hedgepeth, and have interviewed 2,000 people, with DNA tests done on 750 of those. They have mapped the relations of many those interviewees with Hedgepeth and each other, and have reportedly narrowed a pool of a thousand possible suspects down to ten. "This is not a [[cold case]]. It's never been a cold case", Chief Blue told Gasparoli in 2016.<ref name="N&O fourth anniversary story" />
A year later Gasparoli said that he believed that the killer was "just outside" Hedgepeth's closest friends and acquaintances. "Good chance this person didn't know [Hedgepeth] or investigators would know who it was," he wrote. They may, however, have been acting out of anger at some grievance she caused to someone closer to her.<ref name="Gaspo fifth anniversary blog post" />
Blue declined to answer Gasparoli's question at that time as to whether investigators believed more than one person had been involved. "It's a piece of the puzzle we do not have if we connect the direct physical evidence," Celisa Lehew, who took over the case as the department's new chief investigator in 2016, told the reporter regarding that theory. "There was some knowledge that two people lived there."<ref name="N&O fourth anniversary story" />
Speculation has sometimes focused on Rosario, Hedgepeth's roommate at the time, due to her 9-1-1 call, the last texts sent from Hedgepeth's phone to her former boyfriend suggesting "[Rosario] needs you more than you know", the woman addressed as "Rosie" on the voicemail conversation and her decision to leave the apartment unlocked with, she claims, a sleeping Hedgepeth inside, to go sleep somewhere else at 4:30 the morning of the killing. Although she has left North Carolina and said very little about the case since then, Gasparoli wrote in 2017 that he learned from his police sources that they still regularly speak with her, and she cooperates. "They do believe there is more Rosario can tell them," he says. "[It] sounds to me like [Rosario] has been in the crosshairs ... as a key figure who knows more than she says she knows."<ref name="Gaspo fifth anniversary blog post" />

==External links== *[http://www.documentcloud.org/documents/1283962-hedgepeth-case-files.html Case documents released in 2014] {{DEFAULTSORT:Hedgepeth, Faith}} [[Category:2012 murders in the United States]] [[Category:Unsolved murders in the United States]] [[Category:Murder in North Carolina]] [[Category:Deaths by beating in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths by person in the United States]] [[Category:Violence against women in the United States]] [[Category:Incidents of violence against women]] [[Category:University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill events]] [[Category:2012 in North Carolina]] [[Category:September 2012 crimes]]

{{Infobox storm | name = Four-State Tornado Swarm | image = | alt = | caption = | type = Tornado outbreak | active = August 15, 1787 | lowest pressure = | lowest temperature = | tornadoes = ≥5 | fujitascale = Unrated | tornado duration = 3.5+ hours | highest winds = | hail = | gusts = | maximum snow = | power outages = | total fatalities = 2 fatalities, ≥15 injuries | damages = Unknown | affected = [[New England]] | current advisories = | enhanced = | notes = }} The '''Four-State Tornado Swarm''' was a destructive outbreak of [[tornado]]es in [[New England]] on August 15, 1787. At least five separate tornadoes caused major damage in the states of [[Connecticut]], [[Rhode Island]], [[Massachusetts]], and [[New Hampshire]]. Two people were killed by a tornado in [[Wethersfield, Connecticut]], and many were injured throughout New England. This event is considered to be the first true [[tornado outbreak]] on record.<ref name="Grazulis">Grazulis, pg. 553</ref><ref>[http://wmo.asu.edu/tornado-largest-tornado-outbreak Tornado: Largest Tornado Outbreak] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926235427/http://wmo.asu.edu/tornado-largest-tornado-outbreak |date=2013-09-26 }}. ''[[Arizona State University]]''. Accessed June 25, 2009.</ref><!--This online source provided to ease WP:DYK progress; the same info is contained in the book source--> __TOC__ {{clear}}
==Synopsis== [[File:Four-State Tornado Swarm.PNG|thumb|250px|A map of towns which reported damage. Not all of these damage areas were definitely [[tornado|tornadic]], and some tornadoes hit more than one town.<ref name="Grazulis"/><ref name="Ludlam 12"/>]] The first storm damage occurred in [[Litchfield, Connecticut]], where a strong northwest wind and [[hail]] stones weighing more than {{convert|1|oz|g}} damaged crops and broke windows. Four men were struck by lightning, but survived.<ref>{{cite news | title = Litchfield, August 20 | author = No Author | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=18&did=838184602&SrchMode=1&sid=4&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1245891146&clientId=61720 | format = PDF | publisher = [[The Hartford Courant|The Connecticut Courant and Weekly Intelligencer]] | location = Hartford, Connecticut | date = August 27, 1787 | page = 3 | accessdate = June 25, 2009 }}</ref>
The first tornado touched down near [[New Britain, Connecticut]], between 1 p.m. and 2 p.m., moving east-northeast. A barn roof was blown {{convert|2|mi|km}} away. The tornado then passed through [[Newington, Connecticut|Newington]] on its way to [[Wethersfield, Connecticut|Wethersfield]]. The tornado there was described as "[whirling] with amazing velocity and a most tremendous roar."<ref name="Grazulis"/> It passed through a mostly-uninhabited part of the town; if the path were more than {{convert|0.5|mi|km|sigfig=1}} further north or south, the tornado "would have been fatal to a large number of families."<ref name="Wethersfield">{{cite news | title = An Account of the late hurricane at Wethersfield | author = J. Lewis | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=0&did=838184472&SrchMode=2&sid=3&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1244610276&clientId=61720 | format = PDF | publisher = [[The Hartford Courant|Connecticut Courant and Weekly Intelligencer]] | location = Hartford, Connecticut | date = August 20, 2009 | page = 3 | accessdate = June 10, 2009 }}</ref> The tornado traveled slightly north of east, and struck just one home. The inhabitants fled the house upon the sight of the tornado: two young boys, a laborer, and a mother and baby were overtaken by the tornado in a nearby field. The two boys were found amid some rubble, one dead and one was "feared mortally wounded." The mother was killed as well, but the baby who was in her arms survived with only minor injuries. The laborer was thrown over a fence but only slightly injured.<ref name="Wethersfield"/> Their house was unroofed, and several outbuildings were "leveled with the ground". Clothes from the house were found three miles away, and trees and boards were carried {{convert|0.5|mi|km|sigfig=1}} or more.<ref name="Grazulis"/>
The tornado continued east-northeast from Wethersfield, leveling almost all trees in its path, until it reached [[Glastonbury, Connecticut|Glastonbury]].<ref name="Wethersfield"/> There it damaged several homes and barns, including an unroofing of a large brick home, but only injured two people slightly. The damage continued into at least [[Bolton, Connecticut|Bolton]] and [[Coventry, Connecticut|Coventry]], where more damage was done, but any specific damage done or human casualties are unknown.<ref name="Grazulis"/><ref name="Wethersfield"/>
The second tornado was spotted west of [[East Windsor, Connecticut|East Windsor]]. It moved northeast away from the center of town, but did damage to a home and a barn. Trees {{convert|2.5|ft|m}} in diameter were twisted down, and even sod and stones "of a considerable size" were torn up.<ref name="Wethersfield"/><ref name="Ludlam 15">Ludlam, pg. 15</ref> No injuries were reported, however.
The third tornado of the outbreak was a long-tracked tornado, first spotted in [[Killingly, Connecticut]]. It moved northeast into [[Rhode Island]] to near [[Glocester, Rhode Island|Glocester]]. Orchards were destroyed there, and a house and barn were "torn to pieces" while the family took shelter in the cellar.<ref name="Glocester">{{cite news | title = Glocester, August 17, 1787 | author = No Author | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=5&did=837077472&SrchMode=2&sid=4&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1245889587&clientId=61720 | format = PDF | publisher = The Connecticut Courant and Weekly Intelligencer | location = Hartford, Connecticut | date = September 3, 1787 | page = 2 | accessdate = June 25, 2009 }}</ref> Several other homes were unroofed, and a woman was carried some distance, but only suffered minor injuries.<ref name="Glocester"/> The tornado continued northeast into [[Massachusetts]] as far as [[Mendon, Massachusetts|Mendon]], {{convert|20|mi|km}} from where it touched down.<ref name="Gloucester">{{cite news | title = Goucester, August 17, 1787 | author = No Author | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=5&did=837077472&SrchMode=2&sid=4&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1245889587&clientId=61720 | format = PDF | publisher = The Connecticut Courant and Weekly Intelligencer | location = Hartford, Connecticut | date = September 3, 1787 | page = 2 | accessdate = June 25, 2009 }}</ref>
The fourth known tornado was first spotted near [[Northborough, Massachusetts]]. The tornado caused more severe damage along the border between [[Marlborough, Massachusetts|Marlborough]] and [[Southborough, Massachusetts|Southborough]]. In Marlborough, a barn was thrown from its foundation. A house's roof was destroyed, with pieces scattered {{convert|0.75|mi|km|sigfig=2}} away. In Southborough and [[Framingham, Massachusetts|Framingham]], many structures were damaged. A house in Framingham was destroyed while two women were inside, but they suffered only bruises. The tornado dissipated east of Framingham.<ref name="Ludlam 15"/> Many crops were destroyed by winds and floods.<ref>{{cite news | title = Boston, August 20 | author = No Author | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=20&did=838184582&SrchMode=1&sid=2&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1245908777&clientId=61720 | format = PDF | publisher = [[The Hartford Courant|Connecticut Courant and Weekly Intelligencer]] | location = Hartford, Connecticut | date = August 27, 1787 | page = 3 | accessdate = June 25, 2009 }}</ref>
Observers reported seeing pieces of buildings, furniture, and trees thrown about in the air. Severe tree damage was reported all along the tornado's path. Along the tornado's route, the damage was not more than {{convert|40|rd|ft m}} wide, and in some places was much narrower, though the damage was greatest in these areas.<ref name="Ludlam 15"/><ref name="Ludlam 16">Ludlam, pg. 16</ref>
The final tornado of the day occurred much further north in the town of [[Rochester, New Hampshire]]. A house was lifted from its foundation with eight people inside, but only two were injured. Pieces of the house were found {{convert|3|mi|km}} distant. A barn was "taken and entirely carried off" by the tornado, and was not found. Trees, fences, and crops were leveled along the tornado's path, which was around {{convert|20|rd|ft m}} wide.<ref>{{cite news | title = Portsmouth, August 18 | author = No Author | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=19&did=838184592&SrchMode=1&sid=4&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1245891146&clientId=61720 | format = PDF | publisher = [[The Hartford Courant|The Connecticut Courant and Weekly Intelligencer]] | location = Hartford, Connecticut | date = August 27, 1787 | page = 3 | accessdate = June 25, 2009 }}</ref> Considerable damage also occurred in [[Dunbarton, New Hampshire]] and [[Concord, New Hampshire]], but it is not known if this was not directly connected to the tornado.<ref>Perley, p. 142</ref>
==List of known tornadoes== {| class="wikitable collapsible" width="100%" !colspan="6"|List of confirmed tornadoes — August 15, 1787 |- |'''<center>[[Fujita scale|F#]]'''</center> || <center>'''Location'''</center> || <center>'''County'''</center> || <center>'''Time (UTC)'''</center> || <center>'''Path length'''</center> || <center>'''Damage'''</center> |- |colspan="7" align=center|'''[[Connecticut]]''' |- |bgcolor=#{{storm colour|unknown}} | <big>'''F?'''</big> |'''[[New Britain, Connecticut|New Britain]] to [[Coventry, Connecticut|Coventry]]''' | [[Hartford County, Connecticut|Hartford]], [[Tolland County, Connecticut|Tolland]] |1330 |≥{{convert|5|mi|km|}} |'''2 deaths''' - 10 additional injured. Affected [[New Britain, Connecticut|New Britain]], [[Newington, Connecticut|Newington]], [[Wethersfield, Connecticut|Wethersfield]], [[Glastonbury, Connecticut|Glastonbury]], [[Bolton, Connecticut|Bolton]], and [[Coventry, Connecticut|Coventry]]. |- |bgcolor=#{{storm colour|unknown}} | <big>'''F?'''</big> |'''[[Killingly, Connecticut|Killingly]] to [[Mendon, Massachusetts|Mendon, MA]]''' | [[Windham County, Connecticut|Windham]], [[Providence County, Rhode Island|Providence (RI)]], [[Worcester County, Massachusetts|Worcester (MA)]] |1700 |{{convert|20|mi|km}} |One person was injured. Affected the towns of [[Killingly, Connecticut|Killingly]], [[Glocester, Rhode Island]], and [[Mendon, Massachusetts]]. |- |bgcolor=#{{storm colour|unknown}} | <big>'''F?'''</big> |'''NE of [[East Windsor, Connecticut|East Windsor]]''' |[[Hartford County, Connecticut|Hartford]] |unknown |{{convert|5|mi|km|}} |[[East Windsor, Connecticut|East Windsor]] was affected. |- |colspan="7" align=center|'''[[Massachusetts]]''' |- |bgcolor=#{{storm colour|unknown}} | <big>'''F?'''</big> |'''[[Northborough, Massachusetts|Northborough]] to [[Framingham, Massachusetts|Framingham]]''' |[[Worcester County, Massachusetts|Worcester]], [[Middlesex County, Massachusetts|Middlesex]] |unknown |{{convert|8|mi|km}} |Two people were injured. Affected the towns of [[Northborough, Massachusetts|Northborough]], [[Southborough, Massachusetts|Southborough]], and [[Framingham, Massachusetts|Framingham]]. |- |colspan="7" align=center|'''[[New Hampshire]]''' |- |bgcolor=#{{storm colour|unknown}} | <big>'''F?'''</big> |'''[[Rochester, New Hampshire|Rochester]] area''' |[[Strafford County, New Hampshire|Strafford]] |unknown |unknown |Two people were injured. [[Rochester, New Hampshire|Rochester]] was affected by this tornado. |- |colspan="7"|<small>Sources: Grazulis, pg. 553; Ludlam pgs. 12-16</small> |} {{clear}}
==Historical perspective== This day was the most extensive tornado event on record at the time, and was the most severe tornado outbreak in early New England history, on par only with the [[September 1821 New England tornado outbreak]].<ref name="Grazulis"/><ref name="Ludlam 12">Ludlam, pg. 12</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The Great Tornado of 1821 In New Hampshire |last=Lamb |first=Fred W. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1908 |publisher= |location=Manchester, N.H. |isbn= |page= |pages= |id= |url=https://archive.org/details/greattornadoof1800lamb |accessdate=2009-08-15 |quote= }}</ref> Very few buildings were struck by the tornadoes (though the tornadoes passed close to many highly populated towns) which accounts for the low death toll.<ref name="Ludlam 12"/> However, the destructive potential was high, as indicated by the incredible tree damage in places.<ref name="Ludlam 13">Ludlam, pg. 13</ref>
A document was published in the ''Connecticut Courant'' (now the ''[[Hartford Courant]]'') a few days later, detailing the appearance of "a black column from the earth to the cloud" near [[Wethersfield, Connecticut|Wethersfield]]. This was the most complete description of a tornado on record until the 1830s.<ref name="Ludlam 12"/>
